Mark'd ye the mingling of the city's throng,</br>Each mien, each glance, with expectation bright?</br>Prepare the pageant, and the choral song,</br>The pealing chimes, the blaze of festal light!</br>And hark!  what rumour's gathering sound is nigh?</br>Is it the voice of joy, that murmur deep?</br>Away!  be hush'd!   ye sounds of revelry.</br>Back to your homes, ye multitudes, to weep!</br>Weep!  for the storm hath o'er us darkly past,</br>And England's royal flower is broken by the blast!

Was it a dream?  so sudden and so dread</br>That awful fiat o'er our senses came!</br>So loved, so blest, is that young spirit fled,</br>Whose early grandeur promised years of fame?</br>Oh!  when hath life possess'd, or death destroy'd</br>More lovely hopes, more cloudlessly that smiled?</br>When hath the spoiler left so dark a void?</br>For all is lost — the mother and her child!</br>Our morning-star hath vanish'd, and the tomb</br>Throws its deep lengthen'd shade o'er distant years to come.

Angel of Death!  did no presaging sign</br>Announce thy coming, and thy way prepare?</br>No warning voice, no harbinger was thine,</br>Danger and fear seem'd past — but thou wert there!</br>Prophetic sounds along the earthquake's path</br>Foretel the hour of nature's awful throes;</br>And the volcano, ere it burst in wrath,</br>Sends forth some herald from its dread repose:</br>But thou, dark Spirit!  swift and unforeseen,</br>Cam'st like the lightning's flash, when heaven is all serene.

And she is gone — the royal and the young,</br>In soul commanding, and in heart benign;</br>Who, from a race of kings and heroes sprung,</br>Glow'd with a spirit lofty as her line.</br>Now may the voice she loved on earth so well,</br>Breathe forth her name, unheeded and in vain;</br>Nor can those eyes on which her own would dwell,</br>Wake from that breast one sympathy again:</br>The ardent heart, the towering mind are fled,</br>Yet shall undying love still linger with the dead.

Oh!  many a bright existence we have seen</br>Quench'd, in the glow and fulness of its prime;</br>And many a cherish'd flower, ere now, hath been</br>Cropt, ere its leaves were breathed upon by time.</br>We have lost heroes in their noon of pride,</br>Whose fields of triumph gave them but a bier;</br>And we have wept when soaring genius died,</br>Check'd in the glory of his mid career!</br>But here our hopes were center'd — all is o'er.</br>All thought in this absorb'd — she was — and is no more!

We watch'd her childhood from its earliest hour,</br>From every word and look blest omens caught;</br>While that young mind developed all its power,</br>And rose to energies of loftiest thought.</br>On her was fix'd the patriot's ardent eye,</br>One hope still bloom'd — one vista still was fair;</br>And when the tempest swept the troubled sky,</br>She was our dayspring — all was cloudless there;</br>And oh!  how lovely broke on England's gaze,</br>E'en through the mist and storm, the light of distant days.

Now hath one moment darken'd future years,</br>And changed the track of ages yet to be!—</br>Yet, mortal!  'midst the bitterness of tears,</br>Kneel, and adore th' inscrutable decree!</br>Oh!  while the clear perspective smiled in light,</br>Wisdom should then have temper'd hope's excess,</br>And, lost One!  when we saw thy lot so bright,</br>We might have trembled at its loveliness:</br>Joy is no earthly flower—  nor framed to bear,</br>In its exotic bloom, life's cold, ungenial air.

All smiled around thee — Youth, and Love, and Praise,</br>Hearts all devotion and all truth were thine!</br>On thee was riveted a nation's gaze,</br>As on some radiant and unsullied shrine.</br>Heiress of empires!  thou art pass'd away,</br>Like some fair vision, that arose to throw,</br>O'er one brief hour of life, a fleeting ray,</br>Then leave the rest to solitude and wo!</br>Oh!  who shall dare to woo such dreams again!</br>Who hath not wept to know, that tears for thee were vain?

Yet there is one who loved thee — and whose soul</br>With mild affections nature form'd to melt;</br>His mind hath bow'd beneath the stern control</br>Of many a grief — but this shall be unfelt!</br>Years have gone by — and given his honour'd head</br>A diadem of snow — his eye is dim—</br>Around him Heaven a solemn cloud hath spread,</br>The past, the future, are a dream to him!</br>Yet, in the darkness of his fate, alone</br>He dwells on earth, while thou, in life's full pride art gone!

The Chastener's hand is on us — we may weep,</br>But not repine — for many a storm hath past,</br>And, pillow'd on her own majestic deep,</br>Hath England slept, unshaken by the blast!</br>And War hath raged o'er many a distant plain,</br>Trampling the vine and olive in his path;</br>While she, that regal daughter of the main,</br>Smiled, in serene defiance of his wrath!</br>As some proud summit, mingling with the sky,</br>Hears calmly far below the thunders roll and die.

Her voice hath been th' awakener — and her name</br>The gathering word of nations — in her might,</br>And all the awful beauty of her fame,</br>Apart she dwelt, in solitary light.</br>High on her cliffs, alone and firm she stood,</br>Fixing the torch upon her beacon-tower;</br>That torch, whose flame, far streaming o'er the flood,</br>Hath guided Europe through her darkest hour</br>Away, vain dreams of glory! — in the dust</br>Be humbled, ocean-queen!  and own thy sentence just!

Hark!  'twas the death bell's note!  which, full and deep,</br>Unmix'd with aught of less majestic tone,</br>While all the murmurs of existence sleep,</br>Swell'd on the stillness of the air alone!</br>Silent the throngs that fill the darken'd street,</br>Silent the slumbering Thames, the lonely mart;</br>And all is still, where countless thousands meet,</br>Save the full throbbing of the awe-struck heart!</br>All deeply, strangely, fearfully serene,</br>As in each ravaged home th' avenging one had been.

The sun goes down in beauty — his farewell,</br>Unlike the world he leaves, is calmly bright;</br>And his last mellow'd rays around us dwell,</br>Lingering, as if on scenes of young delight.</br>They smile and fade — but, when the day is o'er,</br>What slow procession moves, with measured tread?—</br>Lo!  those who weep, with her who weeps no more,</br>A solemn train — the mourners and the dead!</br>While, throned on high, the moon's untroubled ray</br>Looks down, as earthly hopes are passing thus away.

But other light is in that holy pile,</br>Where, in the house of silence, kings repose;</br>There, through the dim arcade, and pillar'd aisle,</br>The funeral torch its deep-red radiance throws.</br>There pall, and canopy, and sacred strain,</br>And all around the stamp of woe may bear;</br>But Grief, to whose full heart those forms are vain,</br>Grief unexpress'd, unsoothed by them — is there.</br>No darker hour hath Fate for him who mourns,</br>Than when the all he loved, as dust, to dust returns.

We mourn — but not thy fate, departed One!</br>We pity — but the living, not the dead;</br>A cloud hangs o'er us — "the bright day is done,"</br>And with a father's hopes, a nation's fled.</br>And he, the chosen of thy youthful breast,</br>Whose soul with thine had mingled every thought;</br>He, with thine early fond affections blest,</br>Lord of a mind with all things lovely fraught;</br>What but a desert to his eye, that earth,</br>Which but retains of thee the memory of thy worth?

Oh!  there are griefs for nature too intense,</br>Whose first rude shock but stupifies the soul;</br>Nor hath the fragile and o'erlabour'd sense</br>Strength e'en to feel, at once, their dread control.</br>But when 'tis past, that still and speechless hour</br>Of the seal'd bosom, and the tearless eye,</br>Then the roused mind awakes, with tenfold power</br>To grasp the fulness of its agony!</br>Its death-like torpor vanish'd — and its doom;</br>To cast its own dark hues o'er life and nature's bloom.

And such his lot, whom thou hast loved and left.</br>Spirit!  thus early to thy home recall'd!</br>So sinks the heart, of hope and thee bereft,</br>A warrior's heart, which danger ne'er appall'd.</br>Years may pass on — and, as they roll along,</br>Mellow those pangs which now his bosom rend;</br>And he once more, with life's unheeding throng,</br>May, though alone in soul, in seeming blend;</br>Yet still, the guardian-angel of his mind</br>Shall thy loved image dwell, in Memory's temple shrined.

Yet must the days be long ere time shall steal</br>Aught from his grief whose spirit dwells with thee;</br>Once deeply bruised, the heart at length may heal,</br>But all it was — oh!  never more shall be.</br>The flower, the leaf, o'erwhelm'd by winter snow,</br>Shall spring again, when beams and showers return</br>The faded cheek again with health may glow,</br>And the dim eye with life's warm radiance burn;</br>But the pure freshness of the mind's young bloom,</br>Once lost, revives alone in worlds beyond the tomb.

But thou — thine hour of agony is o'er,</br>And thy brief race in brilliance hath been run,</br>While Faith, that bids fond nature grieve no more,</br>Tells that thy crown — though not on earth — is won.</br>Thou, of the world so early left, hast known</br>Nought but the bloom and sunshine — and for thee,</br>Child of propitious stars!  for thee alone,</br>The course of love ran smooth, and brightly free—</br>Not long such bliss to mortal could be given,</br>It is enough for earth to catch one glimpse of heaven.

What though, ere yet the noonday of thy fame</br>Rose in its glory on thine England's eye,</br>The grave's deep shadows o'er thy prospect came?</br>Ours is that loss — and thou wert blest to die!</br>Thou might'st have lived to dark and evil years,</br>To mourn thy people changed, thy skies o'ercast;</br>But thy spring morn was all undimm'd by tears,</br>And thou wert loved and cherish'd to the last!</br>And thy young name, ne'er breathed in ruder tone,</br>Thus dying, thou hast left to love and grief alone.

Daughter of Kings!  from that high sphere look down,</br>Where still in hope, affection's thoughts may rise;</br>Where dimly shines to thee that mortal crown,</br>Which earth display'd to claim thee from the skies.</br>Look down!  and if thy spirit yet retain</br>Memory of aught that once was fondly dear,</br>Soothe, though unseen, the hearts that mourn in vain,</br>And, in their hours of loneliness — be near!</br>Blest was thy lot e'en here — and one faint sigh,</br>Oh!  tell those hearts, hath made that bliss eternity!</br>
